summary: Script-level visual specifications that dictate visual changes, motion graphics, and pacing to enable dynamic retention editing.

core_principles.description: Script must include visual directions for every section to prevent static talking-head shots that cause retention drops
Visual instructions must be detailed about camera angles, pacing, and shot types rather than vague descriptions
Kinetic typography and graphics should be scripted to sync precisely with spoken content for dual coding
Use punctuation and script markup to indicate natural cut points and delivery emphasis
Visual state should change every 3-5 seconds through cuts, zooms, overlays, or graphics

techniques.name: B-Roll Injection Directives
techniques.description: Specific, detailed visual instructions for illustrative footage that syncs with narrative content
implementation: Replace generic descriptions ('Host talks about X') with specific shot lists
Include camera angles: 'low angle', 'drone shot', 'close-up', 'wide shot'
Specify shot duration: 'rapid 1.5-second cut', 'slow 4-second pan'
Match visual rhythm to verbal rhythm (fast-paced speech = rapid cuts)
Plan B-roll for every 10-20 seconds of A-roll dialogue
Note color grading intent for B-roll integration
examples: 'B-roll: Low angle shot of boots hitting mud, RAPID CUT to drone shot of summit'
'Cut to: Close-up of hands typing, reveal screen, zoom out to show workspace'
'B-roll montage: 4 shots in 6 seconds - product, reaction, result process'
'Insert: Slow motion 2-second shot of water droplet hitting surface'

pros_cons.pro: Matches visual pacing to narrative flow

techniques.name: Motion Design Prompts
techniques.description: Script explicit instructions for kinetic typography, data visualization, and animated graphics
implementation: Specify text animation timing: 'animates in sync with word X'
Define animation style: 'pop on', 'slide from left', 'typewriter', 'scale up'
Call out data visualizations: 'bar chart shows growth', 'pie chart with labeled segments'
Request specific text attributes: 'bold yellow text', 'white outline stroke', 'shaking effect'
Plan graphic appearance and disappearance timing
Specify color coding for visual hierarchy
techniques.timing: As needed to support key information or emphasis
examples: 'Text on screen: 50% RETENTION - animates in sync with word retention, bold red'
'Kinetic typography: 3 bullet points stagger in as narrator speaks them'
'Data viz: Line chart rises from 0 to 100 as narrator describes growth'
'Overlay text: 'PRO TIP' in yellow banner with drop shadow'

pros_cons.pro: Reinforces message through dual coding (audio + visual)
Provides engaging visuals for audio-only viewers

techniques.name: Pacing Notation in Scripts
techniques.description: Use punctuation, formatting, and marks to guide speaker delivery and editor cut points
implementation: Use commas for short pauses (0.5-1 second)
Use ellipses for dramatic pauses (2+ seconds)
Bold or italicize key words for emphasis
Use ALL CAPS for shouted or emphasized delivery
Mark sections for SPEED UP or SLOW DOWN
Add [PAUSE], [BEAT], or musical cues
Use [CUT HERE] or [TRANSITION] markers for editor
Note where to hold for visual emphasis
examples: 'You need to MASTER [CUT] this skill [SPEED UP] or you'll fail'

pros_cons.pro: Provides natural cut points for editor

pros_cons.con: Over-notation can make script harder to read aloud

techniques.name: Visual Change Frequency Planning
techniques.description: Plan visual state changes at regular intervals to reset viewer attention
implementation: Mark visual change points every 3-5 seconds in script
Vary change types: hard cut, punch-in, overlay, zoom, B-roll, graphic
Use harder resets (full-screen graphics) every 30-60 seconds
Plan subtle motion (dynamic zoom) for static shots
Note when visual complexity needs to decrease for clarity
Coordinate changes with content emphasis points
techniques.timing: Every 3-5 seconds minimum, varying change type
examples: Narrate complex topic → [B-ROLL INSERT] demonstration → [OVERLAY] summary text
Static shot → [DYNAMIC ZOOM] throughout → [PUNCH-IN] on key word
Dialogue section → [FULL-SCREEN GRAPHIC] data show → return to dialogue
Long explanation → break into [4 VISUAL SECTIONS] with text headers
tools: Script templates with visual change checkpoints

pros_cons.con: Can feel chaotic if not varied appropriately

pros_cons.pro: Creates predictable rhythm viewers can follow
pros_cons.con: Requires constant visual planning and assets

techniques.name: AV Script Format
techniques.description: Two-column format separating auditory content from visual directives for comprehensive pre-production planning
implementation: Left column: Voiceover, dialogue, sound cues
Right column: Visual shots, graphics, camera moves, text overlays
Align timing so each audio line has paired visual direction
Identify 'visual gaps' where no visual change is planned
Fill gaps with B-roll, graphics, or camera movement
Add third column for notes (timing, effects, transitions)
Use for complex explainers, documentaries, tutorials
examples: Audio: 'The mountains rise dramatically' | Visual: Drone shot of mountain range, slow flyover
Audio: 'This setting is hidden' | Visual: Close-up of hidden setting UI, zoom in animation
Audio: 'Three options exist' | Visual: Text overlay: 1, 2, 3 in boxes

pros_cons.pro: Forces comprehensive visual planning, reveals gaps
pros_cons.con: More time-consuming than standard prose scripts

pros_cons.pro: Clear communication between writer, director, and editor
pros_cons.con: May feel restrictive for certain content types
